elements.content: Herein, a microporous NbO-type framwork (FJI-H23) that showed outstanding surface area (3740.4 m2·g–1) was fabricated by utilizing an azobenzene-derived carboxylate ligand. As anticipated, FJI-H23 can store 2.35 wt % H2 at 77 K up to 1 bar. Furthermore, FJI-H23 exhibits high-capacity storage of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons at room temperature. Especially, the uptake amount of C3H8 is 325.76 cm3·g–1 at 298 K, which represents the new record of C3H8 adsorption capacity in the MOFs materials. In addition, FJI-H23 exhibits excellent gravimetric total uptake of 332 cm3·g–1 at 298 K and 65 bar.
elements.clean_text: Herein, a microporous NbO-type framwork (FJI-H23) that showed outstanding surface area (3740.4 m2⋅g-1) was fabricated by utilizing an azobenzene-derived carboxylate ligand. As anticipated, FJI-H23 can store 2.35 wt % H2 at 77 K up to 1 bar. Furthermore, FJI-H23 exhibits high-capacity storage of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons at room temperature. Especially, the uptake amount of C3H8 is 325.76 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K, which represents the new record of C3H8 adsorption capacity in the MOFs materials. In addition, FJI-H23 exhibits excellent gravimetric total uptake of 332 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K and 65 bar.

elements.content: An azobenzene decorated NbO-type MOF shows excellent adsorption capacity of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons as well as highly selective separation of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions. In addition, it shows both very high gravimetric and volumetric CH4 total uptake of 332 cm3·g−1 and 179 cm3·cm−3 at 298 K and 65 bar, respectively.
elements.clean_text: An azobenzene decorated NbO-type MOF shows excellent adsorption capacity of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons as well as highly selective separation of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions. In addition, it shows both very high gravimetric and volumetric CH4 total uptake of 332 cm3⋅g-1 and 179 cm3⋅cm-3 at 298 K and 65 bar, respectively.

elements.content: As is known to all, traditional fuels are extensively used in the national economy, but they usually cause a lot of pollution to the environment. Therefore, the global energy crisis is an important problem waiting to be solved. It is a significant task for researchers to explore the utilization of environment friendly renewable energy. H2 and CH4 have always been regarded as the most suitable clean energy because of their profusion, availability, and renewability. However, storage and transportation is still the big obstacle to preclude these clean energy fuels from wide use. However, natural gas mainly consists of CH4, along with the impurity such as C2H6 and C3H8. It is urgent to remove other hydrocarbons from CH4 to efficiently utilize natural gas. Metal–organic frameworks (abbreviated as MOFs) hold outstanding surface areas, adjustable pore structures, and enriched metal sites and have been widely utilized as the promising candidates for energy gas storage or separation.
elements.clean_text: As is known to all, traditional fuels are extensively used in the national economy, but they usually cause a lot of pollution to the environment. Therefore, the global energy crisis is an important problem waiting to be solved. It is a significant task for researchers to explore the utilization of environment friendly renewable energy. H2 and CH4 have always been regarded as the most suitable clean energy because of their profusion, availability, and renewability. However, storage and transportation is still the big obstacle to preclude these clean energy fuels from  wide use. However, natural gas mainly consists of CH4, along with the impurity such as C2H6 and C3H8. It is urgent to remove other hydrocarbons from CH4 to efficiently utilize natural gas. Metal-organic frameworks (abbreviated as MOFs) hold outstanding surface areas, adjustable pore structures, and enriched metal sites and have been widely utilized as the promising candidates for energy gas storage or separation.

elements.content: Among the MOFs previously reported, the Cu­(II)-MOFs which are constructed by the paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 clusters and m-benzenedicarboxylate subunits have attracted broad attention. Highly symmetric pore structures, high BET surface areas as well as rich open Cu­(II) sites enable this kind of porous materials to efficiently store and separate the gases. For example, the famous MOFs such as HKUST-1, PCN-14, MOF-505, NOTT-101, UTSA-75, and NJU-Bai 41 have been studied for energy gas storage or separation. Our group also exploited a series of Cu-MOFs. For example, FJI-H5 shows high capacity of H2 and CH4 storage at high-pressure conditions. FJI-H8 exhibits an ultrahigh C2H2 uptake at 295 K (224 cm3·g–1). Following the previous work, we introduce the synthesis and characterization of FJI-H23 (formulated as [Cu­(BCAB)0.25(H2O)] n ·4nDMF·3nH2O), which is based on an azobenzene-derived tetracarboxylate ligand H4BCAB (H4BCAB = (E)-4′,4‴-(diazene-1,2-diyl)­bis­(([1,1′-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid)) and the classical dinuclear Cu2(COO)4 clusters. As anticipated, FJI-H23 exhibits high uptake of H2 (2.35 wt % at 77 K and 1 bar) and C2 and C3 hydrocarbons. In particular, the uptake of C3H8 is up to 361.89 cm3·g–1 (273 K) and 324.85 cm3·g–1 (298 K), which are the records among the documented MOF materials. In addition, high-pressure tests show that FJI-H23 possesses a CH4 total adsorption capacity of 332 cm3·g–1 (179 cm3·cm–3) at the condition of 298 K and 65 bar.
elements.clean_text: Among the MOFs previously reported, the Cu(II)-MOFs which are constructed by the paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 clusters and m-benzenedicarboxylate subunits have attracted broad attention. Highly symmetric pore structures, high BET surface areas as well as rich open Cu(II) sites enable this kind of porous materials to efficiently store and separate the gases. For example, the famous MOFs such as HKUST-1, PCN-14, MOF-505, NOTT-101, UTSA-75, and NJU-Bai 41 have been studied for energy gas storage or separation. Our group also exploited a series of Cu-MOFs. For example, FJI-H5 shows high capacity of H2 and CH4 storage at high-pressure conditions. FJI-H8 exhibits an ultrahigh C2H2 uptake at 295 K (224 cm3⋅g-1). Following the previous work, we introduce the synthesis and characterization of FJI-H23 (formulated as [Cu(BCAB)0.25(H2O)] n ⋅4nDMF⋅3nH2O), which is based on an azobenzene-derived tetracarboxylate ligand H4BCAB (H4BCAB = (E)-4',4‴-(diazene-1,2-diyl)bis(([1,1'-biphenyl]-3,5-dicarboxylic acid)) and the classical dinuclear Cu2(COO)4 clusters. As anticipated, FJI-H23 exhibits high uptake of H2 (2.35 wt % at 77 K and 1 bar) and C2 and C3 hydrocarbons. In particular, the uptake of C3H8 is up to 361.89 cm3⋅g-1 (273 K) and 324.85 cm3⋅g-1 (298 K), which are the records among the documented MOF materials. In addition, high-pressure tests show that FJI-H23 possesses a CH4 total adsorption capacity of 332 cm3⋅g-1 (179 cm3⋅cm-3) at the condition of 298 K and 65 bar.

elements.content: FJI-H23 crystallizes in R3̅m space group, which is the same as that of the famous NOTT series. The asymmetric unit is composed of a quarter of fully deprotonated BCAB4– ligands, one crystallographically independent Cu­(II) ion and one coordinated water molecule. One BCAB4– ligand attaches four dicopper­(II) SBUs, while each dicopper­(II) SBU is satisfied with four BCAB4– ligands. Similar to the NOTT series, two types of cages are alternately arranged in the framework. Cage A is composed of six Cu2 paddlewheels and six full deprotonation BCAB4– ligands. Cage B is an octahedron, which is composed of 12 Cu2 paddlewheels and six full deprotonation BCAB4– ligands (). The spherical [Cu6(BCAB)6] cage A is about 22.07 Å in diameter while the [Cu24(BCAB)6] cage B is elongated up to 41.70 Å along the axial direction. Upon packing, there are hexagonal channels along the crystallographic c axis (approximately 15.15 Å × 20.46 Å).
elements.clean_text: FJI-H23 crystallizes in R3̅m space group, which is the same as that of the famous NOTT series. The asymmetric unit is composed of a quarter of fully deprotonated BCAB4- ligands, one crystallographically independent Cu(II) ion and one coordinated water molecule. One BCAB4- ligand attaches four dicopper(II) SBUs, while each dicopper(II) SBU is satisfied with four BCAB4- ligands. Similar to the NOTT series, two types of cages are alternately arranged in the framework. Cage A is composed of six Cu2 paddlewheels and six full deprotonation BCAB4- ligands. Cage B is an octahedron, which is composed of 12 Cu2 paddlewheels and six full deprotonation BCAB4- ligands (). The spherical [Cu6(BCAB)6] cage A is about 22.07 Å in diameter while the [Cu24(BCAB)6] cage B is elongated up to 41.70 Å along the axial direction. Upon packing, there are hexagonal channels along the crystallographic c axis (approximately 15.15 Å × 20.46 Å).

elements.content: Crystal structure analyses of FJI-H23. Two types of cages in FJI-H23 (a) and (b). The hexagonal channels extended parallel to the crystallographic c axis (c).
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure analyses of FJI-H23. Two types of cages in FJI-H23 (a) and (b). The hexagonal channels extended parallel to the crystallographic c axis (c).

elements.content: The solvent-accessible volume of FJI-H23 was calculated to be 72.9% with PLATON software, which provides sufficient vacancy to accommodate guest molecules. To evaluate the stability of the FJI-H23, we have performed thermal weight analysis (TGA) with the as-synthesized sample (Figure S3). This TGA curve shows that FJI-H23 can be stable up to 300 °C and there is ca. 51.35% weight loss. The above weight loss corresponds to four DMF as well as four water molecules, which matches well with the result of element analysis. In addition, FJI-H23 maintains good stability in DMF, acetonitrile, methanol, acetone, and ethanol (Figure S2). In order to acquire the fully desolvated FJI-H23, the sample was heated and kept in a vacuum for 10 h at 353 K. The X-ray powder diffractions of desolvated FJI-H23 indicate that it still maintains crystallinity after activation. The result of N2 adsorption tests at 77 K exhibits a classical type I isotherm and indicates the microporous nature of FJI-H23 (a). It reaches saturation with 1044.22 cm3·g–1. The calculated BET surface area is 3740.39 m2·g–1. It should be noted that the BET of FJI-H23 is higher than those of NOTT-100 (1640 m2·g–1), NOTT-101 (2316 m2·g–1), and NOTT-102 (2942 m2·g–1). The H2 uptake capacity of FJI-23 is 1.31 wt % (147.13 cm3·g–1) at 87 K (b). It rises to 2.35 wt % (262.98 cm3·g–1) at 77 K, which is at the high level for the reported MOFs. The zero-coverage H2 adsorption enthalpy of FJI-H23 achieves 8.38 kJ·mol–1 in the theoretical calculation according to the H2 adsorption isotherms under the temperature of 77 and 87 K. The high capacity of H2 may be attributed to the large open copper sites and moderate pores in the framework.

To evaluate the stability of the FJI-H23, we have performed thermal weight analysis (TGA) with the as-synthesized sample (Figure S3). This TGA curve shows that FJI-H23 can be stable up to 300 °C and there is ca. 51.35% weight loss. The above weight loss corresponds to four DMF as well as four water molecules, which matches well with the result of element analysis. In addition, FJI-H23 maintains good stability in DMF, acetonitrile, methanol, acetone, and ethanol (Figure S2). In order to acquire the fully desolvated FJI-H23, the sample was heated and kept in a vacuum for 10 h at 353 K. The X-ray powder diffractions of desolvated FJI-H23 indicate that it still maintains crystallinity after activation. The result of N2 adsorption tests at 77 K exhibits a classical type I isotherm and indicates the microporous nature of FJI-H23 (a). It reaches saturation with 1044.22 cm3⋅g-1. The calculated BET surface area is 3740.39 m2⋅g-1. It should be noted that the BET of FJI-H23 is higher than those of NOTT-100 (1640 m2⋅g-1), NOTT-101 (2316 m2⋅g-1), and NOTT-102 (2942 m2⋅g-1). The H2 uptake capacity of FJI-23 is 1.31 wt % (147.13 cm3⋅g-1) at 87 K (b). It rises to 2.35 wt % (262.98 cm3⋅g-1) at 77 K, which is at the high level for the reported MOFs. The zero-coverage H2 adsorption enthalpy of FJI-H23 achieves 8.38 kJ⋅mol-1 in the theoretical calculation according to the H2 adsorption isotherms under the temperature of 77 and 87 K. elements.content: N2 isotherms of FJI-H23 at 77 K (a). H2 isotherms of FJI-H23 at different temperatures (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  N2 isotherms of FJI-H23 at 77 K (a). H2 isotherms of FJI-H23 at different temperatures (b).

elements.content: In previous reports, the NbO-type MOFs with functional sites, regular and well-defined channels exhibited higher CH4 storage capacity. To further systematically investigate the uptakes of FJI-H23, high-pressure CH4 adsorption tests were performed (). FJI-H23 exhibits a gravimetric uptake of 332 cm3·g–1 at 298 K and 65 bar, which is higher than those of HKUST-1, PCN-14, NJI-Bai 41, MOF-519, and many other MOFs (Table S2). Due to the low framework density (0.54 g·cm–3 for FJI-H23), the volumetric uptake of FJI-H23 is 179 cm3·cm–3. In practical applications, the working capacity of adsorbent is more important than total gravimetric/volumetric uptakes. Compared with HKUST-1, LIFM-82, MAF-38, and PCN-14, FJI-H23 exhibits higher gravimetric uptake of working capacity at 65 bar (Table S2).
elements.clean_text: In previous reports, the NbO-type MOFs with functional sites, regular and well-defined channels exhibited higher CH4 storage capacity. To further systematically investigate the uptakes of FJI-H23, high-pressure CH4 adsorption tests were performed (). FJI-H23 exhibits a gravimetric uptake of 332 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K and 65 bar, which is higher than those of HKUST-1, PCN-14, NJI-Bai 41, MOF-519, and many other MOFs (Table S2). Due to the low framework density (0.54 g⋅cm-3 for FJI-H23), the volumetric uptake of FJI-H23 is 179 cm3⋅cm-3. In practical applications, the working capacity of adsorbent is more important than total gravimetric/volumetric uptakes. Compared with HKUST-1, LIFM-82, MAF-38, and PCN-14, FJI-H23 exhibits higher gravimetric uptake of working capacity at 65 bar (Table S2).

elements.content: High-pressure gravimetric CH4 uptake of FJI-H23 at 298 K (a). High-pressure volumetric CH4 uptake of FJI-H23 at 298 K (b).
elements.clean_text: 3  High-pressure gravimetric CH4 uptake of FJI-H23 at 298 K (a). High-pressure volumetric CH4 uptake of FJI-H23 at 298 K (b).

elements.content: Considering the high pore volume of FJI-H23, the experiments for the storage of light hydrocarbons have also been done (). Single-component light hydrocarbons sorption isotherms are performed with the pressure up to 1 bar at different temperatures. The uptakes of FJI-H23 for C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 are 168.50, 144.80, and 140.26 cm3·g–1 at ambient conditions, respectively. It is surprising that the uptakes of FJI-H23 for C3H4, C3H6, and C3H8 rise to 462.40, 350.66, and 325.76 cm3·g–1 at the same conditions, respectively. For example, FJI-H23 has a higher adsorption capacity for C2H6 than does Fe-MOF-74, UTSA-35a, UPC-21, JLU-Liu18, InOF-1, JUC-100, JLU-Liu37, JLU-Liu47, and many other MOFs (Table S3), which is only lower than that of NPC-700. To our best knowledge, FJI-H23 can take up more C2 and C3 hydrocarbons than most MOFs. Especially, the uptake amount of C3H8 is 325.76 cm3·g–1 at 298 K, which holds a new record in C3H8 storage for MOF materials. The activated FJI-H23 can absorb more energy gases when lowering the temperature to 273 K (C2H2, 258.67 cm3·g–1; C2H4, 198.30 cm3·g–1; C2H6, 267.51 cm3·g–1; C3H4, 497.55 cm3·g–1; C3H6, 397.07 cm3·g–1; C3H8, 361.89 cm3·g–1). However, FJI-H23 has a much lower capacity of CH4 storage (25.49 cm3·g–1, 273 K; 15.19 cm3·g–1, 298 K). More importantly, the uptakes for C3 hydrocarbons tend to saturation at low pressure, indicating the gases may strongly interact with the framework. Such great differences in the uptakes and the interactions indicate that FJI-H23 may possess a good ability for the separation C3 hydrocarbons and CH4.

Single-component light hydrocarbons sorption isotherms are performed with the pressure up to 1 bar at different temperatures. It is surprising that the uptakes of FJI-H23 for C3H4, C3H6, and C3H8 rise to 462.40, 350.66, and 325.76 cm3⋅g-1 at the same conditions, respectively. For example, FJI-H23 has a higher adsorption capacity for C2H6 than does Fe-MOF-74, UTSA-35a, UPC-21, JLU-Liu18, InOF-1, JUC-100, JLU-Liu37, JLU-Liu47, and many other MOFs (Table S3), which is only lower than that of NPC-700. To our best knowledge, FJI-H23 can take up more C2 and C3 hydrocarbons than most MOFs. The activated FJI-H23 can absorb more energy gases when lowering the temperature to 273 K (C2H2, 258.67 cm3⋅g-1; C2H4, 198.30 cm3⋅g-1; C2H6, 267.51 cm3⋅g-1; C3H4, 497.55 cm3⋅g-1; C3H6, 397.07 cm3⋅g-1; C3H8, 361.89 cm3⋅g-1). However, FJI-H23 has a much lower capacity of CH4 storage (25.49 cm3⋅g-1, 273 K; 15.19 cm3⋅g-1, 298 K). More importantly, the uptakes for C3 hydrocarbons tend to saturation at low pressure, indicating the gases may strongly interact with the framework. Such great differences in the uptakes and the interactions indicate that FJI-H23 may possess a good ability for the separation C3 hydrocarbons and CH4.

elements.content: C2 hydrocarbons isotherms for FJI-H23 at different temperatures (a) and (c). C3 hydrocarbons isotherms for FJI-H23 at different temperatures (b) and (d).
elements.clean_text: 4  C2 hydrocarbons isotherms for FJI-H23 at different temperatures (a) and (c). C3 hydrocarbons isotherms for FJI-H23 at different temperatures (b) and (d).

elements.content: In view of the large difference in uptakes and the slopes between CH4 and other hydrocarbons, the IAST is applied to calculate the selectivity for C2 or C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 with molar ratios of 0.5:0.5 (Figure S9). The calculated selectivities for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 (0.5:0.5) are 197.08, 112.71, and 14.70 at 298 K, respectively. However, the selectivities of C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) rise to 847.66 (C3H4/CH4), 435.99 (C3H6/CH4), and 224.47 (C3H8/CH4) at the same conditions, respectively. When the sample is cooled to 273 K, the calculated selectivities of light hydrocarbons/CH4 are up to 205.68 (C2H2/CH4), 181.52 (C2H4/CH4), 17.54 (C2H6/CH4), 5279.83 (C3H4/CH4), 782.14 (C3H6/CH4), and 360.55 (C3H8/CH4), respectively. The selectivities of FJI-H23 for C2H2 or C2H4/CH4 at ambient conditions are at the forefront in the reported MOFs, which are superior to a large amount of documented MOFs materials. As we all know, the selectivities of C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 are much higher than the separation selectivities of UTSA-35a, JUC-100, JLU-Liu46, and many other MOFs (Table S3). On the whole, FJI-H23 is in an excellent position among the MOFs for the adsorption or separation of energy gases.
elements.clean_text: In view of the large difference in uptakes and the slopes between CH4 and other hydrocarbons, the IAST is applied to calculate the selectivity for C2 or C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 with molar ratios of 0.5:0.5 (Figure S9). The calculated selectivities for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 (0.5:0.5) are 197.08, 112.71, and 14.70 at 298 K, respectively. However, the selectivities of C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 (0.5:0.5) rise to 847.66 (C3H4/CH4), 435.99 (C3H6/CH4), and 224.47 (C3H8/CH4) at the same conditions, respectively. When the sample is cooled to 273 K, the calculated selectivities of light hydrocarbons/CH4 are up to 205.68 (C2H2/CH4), 181.52 (C2H4/CH4), 17.54 (C2H6/CH4), 5279.83 (C3H4/CH4), 782.14 (C3H6/CH4), and 360.55 (C3H8/CH4), respectively. The selectivities of FJI-H23 for C2H2 or C2H4/CH4 at ambient conditions are at the forefront in the reported MOFs, which are superior to a large amount of documented MOFs materials. As we all know, the selectivities of C3 hydrocarbons/CH4 are much higher than the separation selectivities of UTSA-35a, JUC-100, JLU-Liu46, and many other MOFs (Table S3). On the whole, FJI-H23 is in an excellent position among the MOFs for the adsorption or separation of energy gases.

elements.content: In summary, we successfully synthesized a Cu2(COO)4 cluster based framework FJI-H23 upon solvothermal reaction. Due to the large surface area and open copper sites, both the low-pressure H2 adsorption and high-pressure CH4 storage capacity of FJI-H23 are at the high level among the reported MOFs. In particular, it exhibits excellent adsorption capacity of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons. In addition, FJI-H23 can highly selectively separate the mixture of light hydrocarbons and CH4 at room temperature. On the whole, FJI-H23 is an interesting Cu-based framework that has the potential for high-capacity storage and separation of natural gas. Finally, we believe that the above-mentioned results may provide a reference for designing and synthesizing robust MOFs for high-capacity storage of energy gases.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we successfully synthesized a Cu2(COO)4 cluster based framework FJI-H23 upon solvothermal reaction. Due to the large surface area and open copper sites, both the low-pressure H2 adsorption and high-pressure CH4 storage capacity of FJI-H23 are at the high level among the reported MOFs. In particular, it exhibits excellent adsorption capacity of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons. In addition, FJI-H23 can highly selectively separate the mixture of light hydrocarbons and CH4 at room temperature. On the whole, FJI-H23 is an interesting Cu-based framework that has the potential for high-capacity storage and separation of natural gas. Finally, we believe that the above-mentioned results may provide a reference for designing and synthesizing robust MOFs for high-capacity storage of energy gases.

cln_elements.content:
Herein, a microporous NbO-type framwork (FJI-H23) that showed outstanding surface area (3740.4 m2·g–1) was fabricated by utilizing an azobenzene-derived carboxylate ligand. As anticipated, FJI-H23 can store 2.35 wt % H2 at 77 K up to 1 bar. Furthermore, FJI-H23 exhibits high-capacity storage of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons at room temperature. Especially, the uptake amount of C3H8 is 325.76 cm3·g–1 at 298 K, which represents the new record of C3H8 adsorption capacity in the MOFs materials. In addition, FJI-H23 exhibits excellent gravimetric total uptake of 332 cm3·g–1 at 298 K and 65 bar.

An azobenzene decorated NbO-type MOF shows excellent adsorption capacity of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons as well as highly selective separation of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions. In addition, it shows both very high gravimetric and volumetric CH4 total uptake of 332 cm3·g−1 and 179 cm3·cm−3 at 298 K and 65 bar, respectively.

The solvent-accessible volume of FJI-H23 was calculated to be 72.9% with PLATON software, which provides sufficient vacancy to accommodate guest molecules. To evaluate the stability of the FJI-H23, we have performed thermal weight analysis (TGA) with the as-synthesized sample (Figure S3). This TGA curve shows that FJI-H23 can be stable up to 300 °C and there is ca. 51.35% weight loss. The above weight loss corresponds to four DMF as well as four water molecules, which matches well with the result of element analysis. In addition, FJI-H23 maintains good stability in DMF, acetonitrile, methanol, acetone, and ethanol (Figure S2). In order to acquire the fully desolvated FJI-H23, the sample was heated and kept in a vacuum for 10 h at 353 K. The X-ray powder diffractions of desolvated FJI-H23 indicate that it still maintains crystallinity after activation. The result of N2 adsorption tests at 77 K exhibits a classical type I isotherm and indicates the microporous nature of FJI-H23 (a). It reaches saturation with 1044.22 cm3·g–1. The calculated BET surface area is 3740.39 m2·g–1. It should be noted that the BET of FJI-H23 is higher than those of NOTT-100 (1640 m2·g–1), NOTT-101 (2316 m2·g–1), and NOTT-102 (2942 m2·g–1). The H2 uptake capacity of FJI-23 is 1.31 wt % (147.13 cm3·g–1) at 87 K (b). It rises to 2.35 wt % (262.98 cm3·g–1) at 77 K, which is at the high level for the reported MOFs. The zero-coverage H2 adsorption enthalpy of FJI-H23 achieves 8.38 kJ·mol–1 in the theoretical calculation according to the H2 adsorption isotherms under the temperature of 77 and 87 K. The high capacity of H2 may be attributed to the large open copper sites and moderate pores in the framework.

In previous reports, the NbO-type MOFs with functional sites, regular and well-defined channels exhibited higher CH4 storage capacity. To further systematically investigate the uptakes of FJI-H23, high-pressure CH4 adsorption tests were performed (). FJI-H23 exhibits a gravimetric uptake of 332 cm3·g–1 at 298 K and 65 bar, which is higher than those of HKUST-1, PCN-14, NJI-Bai 41, MOF-519, and many other MOFs (Table S2). Due to the low framework density (0.54 g·cm–3 for FJI-H23), the volumetric uptake of FJI-H23 is 179 cm3·cm–3. In practical applications, the working capacity of adsorbent is more important than total gravimetric/volumetric uptakes. Compared with HKUST-1, LIFM-82, MAF-38, and PCN-14, FJI-H23 exhibits higher gravimetric uptake of working capacity at 65 bar (Table S2).

Considering the high pore volume of FJI-H23, the experiments for the storage of light hydrocarbons have also been done (). Single-component light hydrocarbons sorption isotherms are performed with the pressure up to 1 bar at different temperatures. The uptakes of FJI-H23 for C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 are 168.50, 144.80, and 140.26 cm3·g–1 at ambient conditions, respectively. It is surprising that the uptakes of FJI-H23 for C3H4, C3H6, and C3H8 rise to 462.40, 350.66, and 325.76 cm3·g–1 at the same conditions, respectively. For example, FJI-H23 has a higher adsorption capacity for C2H6 than does Fe-MOF-74, UTSA-35a, UPC-21, JLU-Liu18, InOF-1, JUC-100, JLU-Liu37, JLU-Liu47, and many other MOFs (Table S3), which is only lower than that of NPC-700. To our best knowledge, FJI-H23 can take up more C2 and C3 hydrocarbons than most MOFs. Especially, the uptake amount of C3H8 is 325.76 cm3·g–1 at 298 K, which holds a new record in C3H8 storage for MOF materials. The activated FJI-H23 can absorb more energy gases when lowering the temperature to 273 K (C2H2, 258.67 cm3·g–1; C2H4, 198.30 cm3·g–1; C2H6, 267.51 cm3·g–1; C3H4, 497.55 cm3·g–1; C3H6, 397.07 cm3·g–1; C3H8, 361.89 cm3·g–1). However, FJI-H23 has a much lower capacity of CH4 storage (25.49 cm3·g–1, 273 K; 15.19 cm3·g–1, 298 K). More importantly, the uptakes for C3 hydrocarbons tend to saturation at low pressure, indicating the gases may strongly interact with the framework. Such great differences in the uptakes and the interactions indicate that FJI-H23 may possess a good ability for the separation C3 hydrocarbons and CH4.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Herein, a microporous NbO-type framwork (FJI-H23) that showed outstanding surface area (3740.4 m2⋅g-1) was fabricated by utilizing an azobenzene-derived carboxylate ligand. As anticipated, FJI-H23 can store 2.35 wt % H2 at 77 K up to 1 bar. Furthermore, FJI-H23 exhibits high-capacity storage of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons at room temperature. Especially, the uptake amount of C3H8 is 325.76 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K, which represents the new record of C3H8 adsorption capacity in the MOFs materials. In addition, FJI-H23 exhibits excellent gravimetric total uptake of 332 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K and 65 bar.

An azobenzene decorated NbO-type MOF shows excellent adsorption capacity of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons as well as highly selective separation of C2 and C3 hydrocarbons over CH4 at ambient conditions. In addition, it shows both very high gravimetric and volumetric CH4 total uptake of 332 cm3⋅g-1 and 179 cm3⋅cm-3 at 298 K and 65 bar, respectively.

The solvent-accessible volume of FJI-H23 was calculated to be 72.9% with PLATON software, which provides sufficient vacancy to accommodate guest molecules. To evaluate the stability of the FJI-H23, we have performed thermal weight analysis (TGA) with the as-synthesized sample (Figure S3). This TGA curve shows that FJI-H23 can be stable up to 300 °C and there is ca. 51.35% weight loss. The above weight loss corresponds to four DMF as well as four water molecules, which matches well with the result of element analysis. In addition, FJI-H23 maintains good stability in DMF, acetonitrile, methanol, acetone, and ethanol (Figure S2). In order to acquire the fully desolvated FJI-H23, the sample was heated and kept in a vacuum for 10 h at 353 K. The X-ray powder diffractions of desolvated FJI-H23 indicate that it still maintains crystallinity after activation. The result of N2 adsorption tests at 77 K exhibits a classical type I isotherm and indicates the microporous nature of FJI-H23 (a). It reaches saturation with 1044.22 cm3⋅g-1. The calculated BET surface area is 3740.39 m2⋅g-1. It should be noted that the BET of FJI-H23 is higher than those of NOTT-100 (1640 m2⋅g-1), NOTT-101 (2316 m2⋅g-1), and NOTT-102 (2942 m2⋅g-1). The H2 uptake capacity of FJI-23 is 1.31 wt % (147.13 cm3⋅g-1) at 87 K (b). It rises to 2.35 wt % (262.98 cm3⋅g-1) at 77 K, which is at the high level for the reported MOFs. The zero-coverage H2 adsorption enthalpy of FJI-H23 achieves 8.38 kJ⋅mol-1 in the theoretical calculation according to the H2 adsorption isotherms under the temperature of 77 and 87 K. The high capacity of H2 may be attributed to the large open copper sites and moderate pores in the framework.

In previous reports, the NbO-type MOFs with functional sites, regular and well-defined channels exhibited higher CH4 storage capacity. To further systematically investigate the uptakes of FJI-H23, high-pressure CH4 adsorption tests were performed (). FJI-H23 exhibits a gravimetric uptake of 332 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K and 65 bar, which is higher than those of HKUST-1, PCN-14, NJI-Bai 41, MOF-519, and many other MOFs (Table S2). Due to the low framework density (0.54 g⋅cm-3 for FJI-H23), the volumetric uptake of FJI-H23 is 179 cm3⋅cm-3. In practical applications, the working capacity of adsorbent is more important than total gravimetric/volumetric uptakes. Compared with HKUST-1, LIFM-82, MAF-38, and PCN-14, FJI-H23 exhibits higher gravimetric uptake of working capacity at 65 bar (Table S2).

Considering the high pore volume of FJI-H23, the experiments for the storage of light hydrocarbons have also been done (). Single-component light hydrocarbons sorption isotherms are performed with the pressure up to 1 bar at different temperatures. The uptakes of FJI-H23 for C2H2, C2H4, and C2H6 are 168.50, 144.80, and 140.26 cm3⋅g-1 at ambient conditions, respectively. It is surprising that the uptakes of FJI-H23 for C3H4, C3H6, and C3H8 rise to 462.40, 350.66, and 325.76 cm3⋅g-1 at the same conditions, respectively. For example, FJI-H23 has a higher adsorption capacity for C2H6 than does Fe-MOF-74, UTSA-35a, UPC-21, JLU-Liu18, InOF-1, JUC-100, JLU-Liu37, JLU-Liu47, and many other MOFs (Table S3), which is only lower than that of NPC-700. To our best knowledge, FJI-H23 can take up more C2 and C3 hydrocarbons than most MOFs. Especially, the uptake amount of C3H8 is 325.76 cm3⋅g-1 at 298 K, which holds a new record in C3H8 storage for MOF materials. The activated FJI-H23 can absorb more energy gases when lowering the temperature to 273 K (C2H2, 258.67 cm3⋅g-1; C2H4, 198.30 cm3⋅g-1; C2H6, 267.51 cm3⋅g-1; C3H4, 497.55 cm3⋅g-1; C3H6, 397.07 cm3⋅g-1; C3H8, 361.89 cm3⋅g-1). However, FJI-H23 has a much lower capacity of CH4 storage (25.49 cm3⋅g-1, 273 K; 15.19 cm3⋅g-1, 298 K). More importantly, the uptakes for C3 hydrocarbons tend to saturation at low pressure, indicating the gases may strongly interact with the framework. Such great differences in the uptakes and the interactions indicate that FJI-H23 may possess a good ability for the separation C3 hydrocarbons and CH4.

metadata.title:
Azobenzene Decorated NbO-Type Metal–Organic
Framework for High-Capacity Storage of Energy Gases
